text:
AARON GORDON: I'm Aaron Gordon,
I'm one of the co-founders

and the COO of Synapse
Virtual Production.

Synapse Virtual
Production is, as we

like to call it, a
second-generation virtual
production company.

And we really wanted to solve
what an end-to-end ecosystem

would look like and
how to scale that

and how to really create gold
standards within that ecosystem.

We have found ourselves
doing a lot of work

with gaming, in the
sense of cross IP,

and also a lot of immersive
physical experiences.

Our company is very
centralized on Unreal Engine.

We like to think we use
the Engine to its fullest.

It offers a lot
more than just some
of the base-level functionality.

And we use it in a ton
of different ways for 3D
camera-tracked pipelines.
All of that's Unreal Engine.

We're using it to
previs our jobs.

We're using it to create
all of the virtual art

department, the digital
assets for our jobs.

For our environments,
we oftentimes

have the need for
background crowds, people,

for even high-fidelity
interaction with people.
And so we use metahumans a lot.

We've started to mix that
into our pipelines a lot.

We did a music video for
Eminem called "Houdini,"

and it really was just an
amazing case study of using
the Engine to its max.

And we had a ton
of fun doing it,

but that was, from greenlight
to finish, like, a few weeks.
Yeah.

I think multidisciplinary
is probably

the best way to describe
the talent that we attract
and our founding ethos.

But we even within that,
we had live broadcast,

we had film and television,
we had advertising,

we had virtual reality
and augmented reality
all covered within that.

There's an underlying truth
about virtual production, which

is it's not only a young space,
it's a young person's space.

And I think it'd be really
good for a lot of students

to recognize this is
that, when a space has

no real history in
its current form past

five years ago or 10 years
ago, it means that it's also

an industry where people
that have been in media

and entertainment or gaming
or other places for decades

don't necessarily have
an advantage over those

coming fresh into
the space because
of its lack of precedent.

It means you can
come out with a fury,

and you can do a lot of
incredible things in the space.

Our stage ops team is
pretty much a young team.

I would categorize transmedia
as probably the most essential

thing that students
should know now.

I think this linear
idea that I am

going to school to
be in this industry,

so I'm going to be this, and
then I'm going to be that,
and I'm going to be that--
I think those days are over.

And I think, with that in mind,
if you look at transmedia,

if you look at pipelines through
an engine like Unreal Engine,

and you look at
the possibilities

that you can walk
away with, I think,

today, more than ever,
generalism is important.

When you think about
transmedia or the convergence

of so many different disciplines
and career paths with one skill

set, it's really
important to focus

on that versus thinking
about specialization.

That's my opinion because
one core skill set

of knowing how to really use
Unreal Engine well, for example,

can put you into five
titan Industries.
You can go into gaming.

You can go into
film and television.
You can go into automotive.
You can go into architecture.

You can go into
advertising, which

is a crossover of
film and television.
You're central to that now.

So I would suggest that anybody
that's really just starting

to explore with an
open mind because you

don't know what the next
opportunity is going to be.

And if you have the
right skill set,

you'll find yourself
very recruitable.
